explanation:
These symbols are needed because MISRA’s for‑loop well‑formedness rule requires examination of the behaviour of any functions called from the target function (the behaviour of the loop body includes called functions). To determine whether any for loops that execute during OS_stat violate the rule you must be able to inspect those functions and the types/macros that affect control/side‑effects in OS_stat itself: 

- OS_CHECK_POINTER: macro invoked at the top of OS_stat — its expansion may contain control flow or calls (and thus for loops) that affect compliance. 
- memset: standard library call used in OS_stat; its implementation (or any wrapper) could contain for loops or side effects relevant to the rule. 
- OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN: size of local_path; required to understand any buffer iteration logic in callees that use this constant. 
- int32 (typedef): the return type of the function; needed for full type context (and to inspect any loops that depend on integer types/width). 
- os_fstat_t (typedef/struct): the object being zeroed and passed to OS_FileStat_Impl; its definition is required to inspect any loops that iterate over or modify its members (inside called functions). 
- OS_SUCCESS: constant tested by OS_stat; required to understand control flow and whether subsequent callees run. 
- OS_TranslatePath: direct callee — must inspect its body for any for loops and whether those loops obey the three clauses and loop‑counter rules. 
- OS_FileStat_Impl: direct callee executed when OS_TranslatePath succeeds — must inspect its body for for loops and whether they are well‑formed. 
- OS_TimeAssembleFromNanoseconds: known callee of OS_FileStat_Impl (per call graph); needed because loops inside it would be part of the overall behaviour. 
- OS_printf: commonly used by OS_TranslatePath and other helpers for reporting; include to inspect any logging wrappers that might contain loops or side effects.

Note: The list focuses on symbols that can produce for‑loops or side effects reachable during OS_stat. If deeper/complete analysis is required, recursively include the callees of OS_TranslatePath and OS_FileStat_Impl (e.g., OS_strnlen, object‑ID helpers, UT stub functions in unit‑test builds) so their loop constructs can also be examined.
